verses.text: After this, Jesus traveled around in Galilee. He did not wish to go about in Judea because the Jewish leaders were seeking to kill him.
verses.comment: Jesus avoids Judea due to threats against his life. This highlights the mounting opposition Jesus faces, setting the stage for later events in Jerusalem—see Mark 9:30-31 for parallels.

verses.text: Now the Jewish Festival of Booths was near.
verses.comment: The Feast of Booths (Tabernacles) was a major pilgrimage festival per Leviticus 23:34, symbolizing God's protection and providence to Israel.

verses.text: So Jesus’ brothers said to him, 'Leave here and go to Judea so your disciples may see the works you are doing.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ relatives urge Him to make His works known in public. This reflects a misunderstanding of His mission; see Matthew 13:55 and Mark 6:3 for identification of His brothers.

verses.text: For no one acts in secret if he seeks to be known openly. If you do these things, show yourself to the world.
verses.comment: The brothers' words echo temptations to display power—compare with Matthew 4:5-7 where Jesus rejects a public spectacle.

verses.text: For even his brothers did not believe in him.
verses.comment: His close kin misunderstood His true identity, fulfilling Mark 3:21. Faith in Jesus often comes later and requires divine revelation.

verses.text: Jesus said to them, 'My time has not yet come, but your time is always ready.'
verses.comment: Jesus speaks of a divinely appointed 'hour'—see John 2:4 and John 12:23. His actions are guided by the Father’s will, not human pressure.

verses.text: The world cannot hate you, but it hates me because I testify that its works are evil.
verses.comment: Christ’s witness exposes the world’s sins, inciting hostility—see John 15:18-19. His confrontation is essential to redemptive history.

verses.text: You go up to the festival. I am not going up to this festival yet, because my time has not fully come.
verses.comment: Jesus delays His appearance, careful to obey the Father’s timing. Some manuscripts say 'not yet'—here, divine timing distinguishes Jesus’ actions.

verses.text: After saying this, he remained in Galilee.
verses.comment: Jesus stays behind, which shows His obedience and patience.

verses.text: But after his brothers had gone up to the festival, he also went up, not openly but in secret.
verses.comment: Jesus makes a private entrance. He chooses quiet humility over public acclaim, foreshadowing His later approach—see John 11:54.

verses.text: The Jewish leaders were searching for him at the festival and saying, 'Where is he?'
verses.comment: The authorities are actively watching for Jesus. Their actions reflect the increasing tension and anticipation surrounding Him.

verses.text: And there was much murmuring among the crowds about him. Some said, 'He is a good man.' Others said, 'No, he deceives the people.'
verses.comment: Public debate over Jesus’ true identity began—foreshadowing division over Christ’s claims, as seen in Matthew 16:13-14.

verses.text: But no one spoke openly about him for fear of the Jewish leaders.
verses.comment: Fear of persecution silences open discussion. See John 9:22, where the threat to confess faith in Christ is evident.

verses.text: About halfway through the festival, Jesus went up to the temple courts and began to teach.
verses.comment: Jesus chooses a public moment to teach in the temple, symbolizing His authority. John 18:20 affirms His openness in teaching.

verses.text: The Jewish leaders were astonished and said, 'How does this man know such letters, never having been taught?'
verses.comment: Jesus displays wisdom beyond human learning—see Matthew 13:54. His divine authority is manifested through His knowledge.

verses.text: Jesus answered them, 'My teaching is not mine, but from him who sent me.'
verses.comment: Jesus claims divine origin for His teaching—see John 5:19-24. This is an implicit claim to messianic authority, rooted in His unity with the Father.

verses.text: If anyone wants to do his will, he will know whether this teaching is from God or if I am speaking on my own authority.
verses.comment: True discernment comes from a desire to obey God—see John 8:31-32. Spiritual insight is connected to openness of heart and obedience.

verses.text: Whoever speaks on his own seeks his own glory. But he who seeks the glory of the one who sent him is true, and there is no unrighteousness in him.
verses.comment: Jesus is the model of humility and righteousness, seeking the Father’s glory. See Mark 10:45—His selfless mission fulfills the prophecy of the righteous servant.

verses.text: Has not Moses given you the Law? Yet none of you keeps the Law. Why do you seek to kill me?
verses.comment: Jesus draws attention to the inconsistency of His opponents—see Exodus 20:1-17. They violate the Law while pretending to defend it.

verses.text: The crowd replied, 'You are possessed! Who is seeking to kill you?'
verses.comment: The accusation of demonic influence mirrors other hostile claims—see Matthew 12:24. Their blindness to the plot reflects spiritual ignorance.

verses.text: Jesus replied, 'I did one work, and you all marvel at it.'
verses.comment: This references the healing at the pool (John 5:8-9), which stirred controversy regarding the Sabbath.

verses.text: Moses gave you circumcision—not that it is from Moses but from the fathers—and you circumcise a man on the Sabbath.
verses.comment: Jesus clarifies circumcision predates Moses (Genesis 17:10-12). He exposes the flexibility in their Sabbath observance.

verses.text: If a man receives circumcision on the Sabbath so that the Law of Moses may not be broken, are you angry with me because I made a man completely well on the Sabbath?
verses.comment: Jesus points out the hypocrisy in Sabbath restrictions; see Matthew 12:12. Healing fulfills the spirit of the Law.

verses.text: Do not judge by appearances, but judge with righteous judgment.
verses.comment: True judgment must align with God’s justice—see Matthew 7:1-2. Spiritual discernment is emphasized.

verses.text: Some of the people from Jerusalem said, 'Is this not the man they are seeking to kill?'
verses.comment: Public awareness of the plot against Jesus is growing—see John 5:18. Tensions escalate leading to His Passion.

verses.text: Yet here he is, speaking openly, and they say nothing to him. Could it be that the authorities know he is truly the Christ?
verses.comment: Some begin to recognize messianic possibilities—see John 1:41 for early confessions of Jesus as the Christ.

verses.text: However, we know where this man comes from. But when the Christ comes, no one will know where he is from.
verses.comment: Confusion arises from messianic expectations—compare with Micah 5:2 where Messiah’s origin is foretold.

verses.text: Then Jesus cried out in the temple, teaching, 'You know me, and you know where I come from. Yet I have not come of my own authority. He who sent me is true, and you do not know him.'
verses.comment: Jesus asserts His divine commission, distinguishing Himself from earthly origins—see John 5:43. High Christology is suggested here.

verses.text: I know him, because I am from him, and he sent me.
verses.comment: Jesus affirms His unique relationship with God—see John 1:18. This is a clear claim to divine origin.

verses.text: So they tried to arrest him, but no one laid a hand on him, because his hour had not yet come.
verses.comment: Divine providence prevents Jesus’ arrest. His 'hour' is determined by God, not men (see John 8:20).

verses.text: Many from the crowd believed in him and said, 'When the Christ comes, will he do more signs than this man has done?'
verses.comment: Faith is born from witnessing signs, connecting to John 2:23—recall the fulfillment in prophecy and signs as authenticating the Christ.

verses.text: The Pharisees heard the crowd whispering these things about him, and the chief priests and Pharisees sent officers to arrest him.
verses.comment: Religious leaders respond to popular belief by seeking Jesus’ arrest, threatening unity in faith, foreshadowing priestly involvement in later events.

verses.text: Then Jesus said, 'I am with you a little while longer, and then I am going to him who sent me.'
verses.comment: Jesus hints at His impending departure and return to the Father—see John 13:1. His dual nature is quietly referenced here.

verses.text: 'You will search for me, but you will not find me. And where I am, you cannot come.'
verses.comment: A prophecy of coming separation—see John 13:33. Spiritual union with Christ is not achieved by mere effort, but by grace.

verses.text: The Jewish leaders said among themselves, 'Where does he intend to go so that we will not find him? Will he go to those dispersed among the Greeks and teach the Greeks?'
verses.comment: Their words unintentionally point to the universality of Jesus’ mission—see Isaiah 49:6, where the Messiah brings light to the nations.

verses.text: 'What does he mean by saying, “You will search for me but will not find me, and where I am you cannot come?”'
verses.comment: Doubts arise over spiritual language. See John 14:3-4, where Jesus speaks of preparing a place for His followers—spiritual union through faith and sacrament.

verses.text: On the last and greatest day of the festival, Jesus stood and cried out, 'If anyone thirsts, let him come to me and drink.'
verses.comment: Jesus uses a public moment to invite all to Himself, fulfilling Isaiah 55:1. Water symbolizes spiritual life, prefiguring the sacraments.

verses.text: 'Whoever believes in me, as the Scripture has said, “Rivers of living water will flow from within him.”'
verses.comment: Fulfillment of prophecy—Isaiah 58:11; Ezekiel 47:1-12. Referencing the indwelling presence of the Spirit and sacramental life.

verses.text: This he said about the Spirit, whom those who believed in him were to receive. For the Spirit had not yet been given, because Jesus was not yet glorified.
verses.comment: This clearly refers to Pentecost (Acts 2:4) and the Spirit’s later outpouring (John 20:22). The flow of living water becomes a reality through Christ’s glorification.

verses.text: Some of the crowd, hearing these words, said, 'Surely this is the Prophet.'
verses.comment: Echoing expectation of the promised Prophet—see Deuteronomy 18:15. This underscores a preparatory Christological expectation.

verses.text: Others said, 'This is the Christ.' But some asked, 'Will the Christ come from Galilee?'
verses.comment: The crowd wrestles with prophecy—Micah 5:2 points to Bethlehem, hinting at Jesus’ hidden fulfillment of messianic expectations.

verses.text: 'Doesn’t the Scripture say that the Christ comes from the descendants of David and from Bethlehem, the village where David lived?'
verses.comment: Referencing prophecies of Davidic lineage and Bethlehem origin—see 2 Samuel 7:12-16 and Micah 5:2. Jesus fulfills these in His hidden birth narrative.

verses.text: So there was division among the people because of him.
verses.comment: Jesus brings a spiritual sword, dividing opinion—see John 9:16. This division persists in the church’s ongoing journey through history.

verses.text: Some wanted to seize him, but no one laid hands on him.
verses.comment: Attempts to arrest Jesus continue to be thwarted by divine protection—see John 10:39.

verses.text: The officers went back to the chief priests and Pharisees, who asked them, 'Why did you not bring him?'
verses.comment: Even temple guards are struck by Jesus’ authority—see John 18:3-6, where Christ’s mere words overcome His captors.

verses.text: The officers answered, 'No one ever spoke like this man.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ speech possesses unique divine authority—see Matthew 7:28-29. His word transcends ordinary teaching.

verses.text: Then the Pharisees answered, 'Are you led astray also?'
verses.comment: Religious leaders accuse their own agents of error, foreshadowing deeper division and authority struggles.

verses.text: Have any of the rulers or Pharisees believed in him?
verses.comment: Leaders question the faith of their own, but silent belief exists among them—see John 12:42.

verses.text: But this crowd that does not know the Law is accursed.
verses.comment: Contempt toward the unlearned reflects spiritual pride. See Hosea 4:6; genuine wisdom comes from humble openness to revelation.

verses.text: Nicodemus, who had come to Jesus earlier and who was one of them, said to them,
verses.comment: Nicodemus appears again—see John 3:1 and John 19:39. He becomes a bridge for understanding Jesus in both law and spirit.

verses.text: 'Does our Law judge a man before it hears him and knows what he has done?'
verses.comment: Nicodemus upholds proper legal process—see Deuteronomy 1:16-17 and Exodus 23:1-3, echoing fair judgment and due process.

verses.text: They replied, 'Are you from Galilee too? Search and you will find that no prophet arises out of Galilee.'
verses.comment: Their claim ignores Isaiah 9:1 and the example of Jonah, who was from Galilee. Sometimes prejudice clouds discernment of prophecy fulfillment.

verses.text: Then each of them went to his own house.
verses.comment: The chapter closes with unresolved tension, setting the stage for deeper revelation and division. This moment invites reflection on collective responsibility and individual response to Christ.
